name: Overview
data:
[{"id":"639fdbac-f811-40fa-9da1-2442de497521","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":3,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Group: Retrieval & Inspection","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"57b35e19-19c2-4cf4-ab28-7a16ab7c764d","type":"paragraph","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This group of methods provides the "read-only" interface for the ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"NamePointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Once arguments have been registered during a function call analysis, these functions allow the engine to query that data. They are essential for "unpacking" arguments: taking the values from a call site and injecting them into the local scope of the function being analyzed.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"8f018d7e-cb73-43a4-a9e0-9ef55fc70276","type":"divider","props":{},"children":[]},{"id":"7d1bc9f3-f6d5-4f35-be76-1e0e221db4b7","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":4,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Methods","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"2fc823b2-2ab4-4ce9-b6c8-f04ce4594e3a","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get_arg(name)
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"The standard lookup for a named argument. It returns the set of all potential values associated with that parameter name. Returns ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"None","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" if the name is not in the registry.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"00d3c4c6-19c5-4836-83c6-60e0e02716da","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get_pos_arg(pos)
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"A positional lookup that first resolves the index (e.g., ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"0","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":") to its mapped name (e.g., ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":""user_id"","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":") and then retrieves the values for that name.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"9c719468-6e01-4e23-aaa3-e853a63d9f9b","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get_args()
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Exposes the entire internal argument dictionary. This is used when the analyzer needs to iterate over every argument passed to a function, such as during a bulk scope update.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"d02111ab-c2f9-476a-91c0-eabf0f24dd64","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get_pos_args()
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Constructs and returns a dictionary where the keys are the positional indices and the values are the sets of data. This is useful for analyzing functions that use ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"*args","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":".","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"b1175c6f-6992-4609-bc71-65595843eff8","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get_pos_of_name(name)
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Performs a reverse lookup to find the index of a named argument. For example, it can determine that the parameter ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":""password"","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" was passed at position ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"2","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":".","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"d413fef6-23f8-4f9d-b9e3-b11b74bbeb73","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get_pos_names()
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Returns the internal map that links indices to parameter names (e.g., ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"{0: "host", 1: "port"}","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"). This is primarily used to resolve the signature of a function.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"fa363796-55bd-428e-9144-47015fe2b77e","type":"divider","props":{},"children":[]},{"id":"98be0d3d-5035-4da6-9692-874429aa9378","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":3,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Usage Example","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"6f7ed48a-ee36-4098-b5f8-438a7c86a8a0","type":"paragraph","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"After arguments have been collected into a ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"NamePointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the analyzer uses these methods to verify the data flow:","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"6d09b16a-921f-4df8-b6ff-79a957403c5a","type":"codeBlock","props":{"language":"python"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"# Assuming np is a NamePointer populated with: np.add_pos_arg(0, "host", "127.0.0.1")

# 1. Retrieve value by name
host_values = np.get_arg("host") 
# Output: {'127.0.0.1'}

# 2. Retrieve value by position
first_arg_values = np.get_pos_arg(0) 
# Output: {'127.0.0.1'}

# 3. Inspect the positional mapping
mappings = np.get_pos_names()
# Output: {0: 'host'}

# 4. Get all arguments for processing a function body
all_data = np.get_args()
for param_name, values in all_data.items():
    print(f"Injecting {values} into local variable {param_name}")","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"62ac1611-3fb5-42c6-9506-ce24d940ea5f","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":3,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Insights","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"43a370d8-76e0-45e4-87ed-49ab3151c71c","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Resolution Logic","styles":{"bold":true}},{"type":"text","text":": ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"get_pos_arg","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a high-level convenience method; it ensures that even if you only know the call order, you can still access the underlying data set tied to the variable name.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"4adc0cba-072a-45d3-b340-de7c1c4a49db","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Robustness","styles":{"bold":true}},{"type":"text","text":": These methods include safety checks (like ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"get()","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" defaults) to handle cases where an analyzer might query an argument that was never actually passed, preventing crashes during the analysis of partial or broken code.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"7c95c04c-55a5-468a-8ab6-c31b855e80e4","type":"paragraph","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[],"children":[]}]
